docs.lead_paragraph: THE capital of the American automotive industry and the capital of American entertainment don't seem to have much in common. Detroit wears Brooks Brothers, Hollywood wears Armani. Detroit eats meat and potatoes, Hollywood (when it's not dieting) dines on sushi and low-carb shakes. Detroit is Rust Belt; Hollywood is Botox Belt. Crucial numbers in Detroit are market share and miles per gallon. In Hollywood, they're box office takes and agents' percentages. In Detroit, silicon can be found in painstakingly engineered auto parts. In Hollywood, silicone can be found in painstakingly engineered body parts.

headline.main: Detroit Is So Hollywood, And Vice Versa

docs.snippet: What the American automotive and entertainment industries have in common is trouble, and perhaps a way out of it.

docs.lead_paragraph: REAL doctors performed real procedures on real patients. The insurance claims were real; so were the surgery centers that filed them. And the money that insurers paid -- a total of about $500 million, federal investigators estimate -- was most assuredly real. Hundreds of people, many of them recent immigrants unfamiliar with America's health care system, volunteered to undergo the medical tests and operations. They traveled to surgery centers in Southern California for what would be, in another context, routine procedures like endoscopies, colonoscopies and pap smears. Some traveled, on the clinics' dime, from as far away as Tennessee. Some of them, investigators say, received free or discounted plastic surgery, and others got cash.

headline.main: In a Surgery Capital, a Swirl of Fraud Charges

docs.snippet: In Southern California, investigators have unraveled what they say is one of the most egregious cases of doctors manipulating the trust placed in them.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the year halfway over, there couldn't be a better time for a personal finance checkup to see whether adjustments are warranted in, say, an investment portfolio or insurance coverage. The trouble is that few people are probably thinking much about financial planning these torpid summer days. ''We find that people generally spend more time planning a vacation than they spend on their finances,'' said Eric Hutchison, the chief executive of Hutchison-Ifrah Financial Services in Little Rock, Ark., ''and that's unfortunate.''

headline.main: Personal Business; To Do: Apply Sunscreen, Get Finance Checkup Personal Business

docs.snippet: With the year halfway over, there couldn't be a better time for a personal finance checkup, but few people are thinking about financial planning these summer days.

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's employers stepped up their hiring in June, the government reported yesterday, adding 146,000 jobs to meet the gradually rising demands of a sturdy economy. The unemployment rate dipped another notch, to 5 percent, the lowest level in nearly four years. The hiring showed up in just about every sector except manufacturing. Still, job creation remained well below average for this stage of a recovery, three and a half years after the 2001 recession ended.

headline.main: Hiring Pace Picked Up Last Month

docs.snippet: The nation's employers stepped up their hiring in June, adding 146,000 jobs to meet the gradually rising demands of a sturdy economy.

docs.lead_paragraph: COORDINATED terror bombings in London shook up an otherwise sleepy week in business and finance. One midsize merger was announced in the United States, even after much of Wall Street seemed to have headed for the Hamptons after the Independence Day holiday. And American automakers renewed their price-cutting showroom fight to the finish. MARKET SHOCK -- The explosions that killed at least 50 people and wounded hundreds more in London briefly unnerved financial and commodities markets around the world, but major indexes rallied after the initial shock passed and recouped about half their losses by the end of the first day. After the second day, European markets had recouped almost all their losses, and American markets were sharply higher. The attacks, which came a day after the city was chosen as the site of the 2012 Summer Olympics, did not close markets in London, the center of foreign-exchange transactions and a major hub of commodities and stock trading.

headline.main: Commerce Shows Resilience as Terrorism Intrudes on a Summer Week

docs.snippet: Coordinated terror bombings in London shook up an otherwise sleepy week in business and finance.

docs.lead_paragraph: At the threshold of Vincent J. Russo's law office here, a sign promises that ''Peace of Mind Is Attainable.'' It is a reassuring beacon for clients who come to see Mr. Russo, an elder-care lawyer, at a time of crisis and confusion.

headline.main: The Middle Class Struggles in the Medicaid Maze

docs.snippet: Medicaid can help pay for long-term care in many situations, but for tens of thousands of the middle class, the hardest part may be learning how to qualify.

docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking a better understanding of how well diabetics are managing the disease, New York City health officials have proposed that all laboratories in the city be compelled to pass along to the health department the results of certain tests that measure blood sugar levels. New York's is the first health department in the country to propose such a mandate, and health officials say the information would provide them with the most extensive system in the nation for tracking control of the disease.

headline.main: City Officials Aim to Track How Diabetics Manage Illness

docs.snippet: New York health officials want all laboratories in the city to pass along the results of certain diabetes tests.

docs.lead_paragraph: State revenues rose significantly in the last year as the nation's recovering economy produced more sales of goods and services and generated more income for individuals and corporations, the National Governors Association reported Thursday. ''The revenue picture for most states improved dramatically in fiscal 2005,'' said the report, based on a survey of state fiscal conditions. The survey was conducted by the governors' group and the National Association of State Budget Officers.

headline.main: After Bleak Period, States' Revenues Rise, Governors Report

docs.abstract: National Governors Association reports rise in state revenues in last year as nation's recovering economy produced more sales of goods and services and generated more income for individuals and corporations; National Association of State Budget Officers reports similar growth, with only three states' revenues falling below budget projections (M)
docs.snippet: States are cautious about the fiscal outlook over the next 5 or 10 years, with health costs still on the rise.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NATIONAL ASSN OF STATE BUDGET OFFICERS

docs.lead_paragraph: The company that recently broke new ground by winning federal approval for the first drug intended for African-Americans could now be entering new territory with a controversial pricing system for the medicine. The maker, NitroMed, has set the price of its heart-failure drug BiDil at $1.80 a pill, significantly higher than what analysts had expected and nearly twice as much as some other heart-failure treatments. Depending on the dosage, that would make the cost of taking BiDil at least $5.40 and maybe as much as $10.80 a day.

headline.main: Maker of Heart Drug Intended for Blacks Bases Price on Patients' Wealth

docs.snippet: The company could now be entering new territory with a controversial pricing system for the medicine.

docs.lead_paragraph: Omnicare, the provider of drugs to nursing homes, agreed yesterday to buy its rival NeighborCare for $1.55 billion in cash, creating an institutional pharmacy behemoth. The friendly deal, which was approved unanimously by the boards of both companies, comes more than a year after Omnicare first made an unsolicited takeover bid in June 2004.

headline.main: Omnicare Buys NeighborCare, A Rival, for $1.55 Billion
